Wishlist: System.Exception constructor to support string formatting

Posted by karlseguin on May 15, 2006

As I’ve indicated in the past, I’m a pretty big fan of string.Format and anything else that accepts a string format (Databinder.Eval, ToString,….). I find myself using string.Format a lot when throwing exceptions:

throw new FuelConfigurationException(string.Format(“Missing required attribute \”{0}\”/“, attributeName));

It’d be cool if the base System.Exception class had a constructor that looked like:

public Exception(string message, params object[] arguments);

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.
← ASP.NET isn’t always the right tool
XSL gives me the warm and fuzzy →

8 Responses to Wishlist: System.Exception constructor to support string formatting

  1. Jeff Handley says:
    June 24, 2006 at 2:04 pm

    Amen! Almost every exception I throw has a String.Format() inside of it. And at least 50% of the time, I start typing the string literal first, have to back up and put in String.Format( … ).

    Yeah, the question about what happens when String.Format throws an expection in the middle is a valid one… but I’d just make it do the same thing that would happen if you have String.Format in there yourself.

  2. Will says:
    May 23, 2006 at 8:39 pm

    Also, what happens if the string.Format you are entering fails and throws an exception during the construction of your exception.

  3. Nick Parker says:
    May 15, 2006 at 9:09 pm

    You could define a base exception that derives from ApplicaionException, avoid the Exception class itself and then provide an overloaded ctor.

  4. johnwood says:
    May 15, 2006 at 5:29 pm

    I agree with Marc. You could apply this argument to every method in the framework that accepts a string. It doesn’t make sense to have it implemented everywhere. That’s why we have string.Format, so the responsibility of string formatting is managed by the string itself.

  5. Marc Brooks says:
    May 15, 2006 at 5:02 pm

    Then there’s always the need to do message localization. I end up with an SR helper class, by which point all those Exception throws end up looking like throw new Exception(SR.FormatString(“ResourceKey”, arg1, arg2)); thus we don’t need another overload…

  6. MB says:
    May 15, 2006 at 4:47 pm

    Well, since FuelConfigurationException is derived, why not just implement it there? String.Format is static, so that shouldn’t be a problem.
    It’d only really be a help for throwing the BCL exceptions, but excepting perhaps ApplicationException (which I do throw on occassion instead of deriving my own type), why would you do that?

  7. karl says:
    May 15, 2006 at 4:09 pm

    Ya, I know it would be a pain in the ass to have a 5th and 6th constructor to implement…

  8. ParanoidPenguin says:
    May 15, 2006 at 2:54 pm

    Might be nice, but it would probably just end up as yet another constructor you need to remember to add to your derived Exceptions.
